So moving forward we'll be using our a new chatroom connected with our local github organization.

The reason for the new room is this (from Quincy Jones): We are archiving all of our chat rooms that don't have a lot of use. By the end of the process, we will only have about 15 rooms total. The reason for this is that people often join rooms, introduce themselves, then don't hear back, which is a negative experience.
Will try to add you all manually, but might miss someone, so please check that you've migrated.
Click the link, or look for FCCVienna/Lobby :)
@all new chatroom (and this time we own it together via github org): https://gitter.im/FCCVienna/Lobby?utm_source=share-link&utm_medium=link&utm_campaign=share-link

@robeerob thanks for feedback Robert! :)

Nicely done, @kiknag and @tatiag :) Love both designs and layouts, plus they seem to work very well. I have two points of feedback that applies to you both: 1) your background images seem to be 1780px (or approx) wide, so when I view it on a bigger monitor it does not look optimal, and 2) you do not seem to account for "user story 6" in the zipline: "I can keep chaining mathematical operations together until I hit the equal button, and the calculator will tell me the correct output.". If I compare your calculator to the linked to example (same for google's calculator) and for example input 85+4*3, I get 112 on your's and 282 on the example calculator.

Well, I am still fiddling around with this, to no avail. I could obviously trash the recursion, because I know the maximum depth of the tested arrays and could iterate through them. But I feel it was a better solution if the nesting depth were irrelevvant. And the only way I see this being possible is by using recursion.
Thanks @MK-61 I will try it out later today and report back
@lukastillmann  i found for you very good and short explanation about recursion with javascript examples. https://www.sitepoint.com/recursion-functional-javascript/
Hint n2: you don't need this "launcher" function, just call flattenArray directly
So, what you should do: function, which takes array, flattens it, and return it. There should be no global variables at all.
And to be honest, FCC interface, task explanation and so on - is far from ideal. That's why so much confusion is here.
I am really bad teacher, sorry for that, but i will help you as much as i can - feel free to ask, i just want to give not right away answer, i just giving you hints for research.

And then - tip above - I said already, check out recursive call of "flattenArray(arr[i]);" - it's your function, which returns array. But there you just call it like simple "procedure", because you designed your function to work with global flattenArray.
And it "works", because finalArray is global. As soon, as you put finalArray inside of flattenArray function (as it should be) - you will see - it doesn't work.
Well, maybe because you did recursive functions and for some strange reason made finalArray globally?
[![blob](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Vienna/5Tu6/thumb/blob.png)](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Vienna/5Tu6/blob)

1. I run this code on FCC and the output is exactly what it is supposed to be, but I still get red Xs 

2. I know, all I need is the last return statement to return back to my main function, don't I? Do you have any tips for me? I'm really not that good with recursion and I was quite happy that it actually worked (in a way)
In this piece of code you recursively calling flattenArray, function, which is returning finalArr, but in this code you do nothing with returned result. Just a hint.

I've tried i3wm, and really like tiling wms, but I can't get myself to use it for everything. Doesn't look "pretty enough", I guess, to have as my main wm. But now that both Unity and Gnome has some tiling shortcuts out of the box, I am very happy using that instead. Love being able to "live in the terminal" for some of my work though. Tmux+vim ftw. uzbl-browser looks interesting, and the fact that uzbl builds on the unix philosophy is appealing
I just really bored of all bloatness, so im into Vim/Neovim since 3 months, and since 2 weeks in 'i3wm', and last bloat which i will kill will be browser - something like 'uzbl'.
Does that mean I am as efficient in vim as I can be in atom? No. But with time I will get there, and then plus some.

Yeah, I've started using it for most workflows. Only thing I go to atom for is large documents I have to diff, and some other convenient stuff, but I know I can do all that atom can with vim with just the right knowledge and atom.

Gitter client is good, but it lacks many settings for me and interface is burdened with "extra" unused space. Or maybe I just blind and didn't found settings yet.

Well, I also using bouncer for it, so I can have any client at mobile also, avoiding all "irc-cloud" like clients which basically offering bouncer but for money, haha. Well, in case of gitter there is no bouncer of course.

robeerob, so far so good, ofc it's faster, tho - gitter client retrieving all history, while HexChat (prolly irc.gitter.im) doesn't allow that. Well, anyway, for chatting it is perfect, and if I need to get something which I missed - I can go in browser/client.
